What about using the mail API, or perhaps some Jabber message API? 
It's se=
rver-side stuff, which tends to be straightforward to write
tests for.  At =
the end you can still plug the output into a GUI to see
the results of the =
application.  Some folks may be already familiar
with these APIs, but you c=
an turn that into an opportunity to make the
point that the kind of tests y=
ou want to write would involve the
content that is sent *via* the APIs, not=
 the adherence to the
standard.

Something like, "whenever x is true, a mes=
sage should be sent to lists
including Y, with message contents z".  Using =
a mail API, and making
assertions about the mail objects created (without s=
ending them
through an actual mail server) would drive home the point that =
you
want to test the message *creation* unit, and not necessarily the
actua=
l round-trip of sending the mail and receiving it.  Once you've
written you=
r tests, you can the fire up the full application and see
it go in a real e=
nough way (assuming you run a little mailserver
locally for this).

This ca=
n be a powerful demonstration of how you can develop code to
APIs using uni=
t tests, even before the implementation is ready.  I've
written a good chuc=
k of code to in-house APIs that were not ready or
had major bugs.

Lastly, =
an illuminating question may be this:  What aspects of Unit
Testing do you =
want to drive home with this example?  I'm guessing
your presentation alrea=
dy has these points, and you want your
courseware to reveal them in a prett=
y obvious way.  Here's some
guesses and some ideas for 'tasks' based on abo=
ve:

Unit tests make development easier.

The initial 'task' of getting the=
 emails/messages sent through the
server is faster because the tests run fa=
ster than the email server. 
If you're using Jabber, claim that the Jabber =
API you're using is only
defined, not implemented.  Heck, that might even b=
e true at the
moment!
 
Unit tests make for easier refactoring.

After the =
initial 'task' is done, tell the users they need to localize
the content me=
ssages, sending them in English and Martian, using a
'translator' that you =
provide.  The initial tests are all still valid
in English, and new ones ar=
e added for Martian.

I think you'll want to have more than one iteration i=
n your example. 
Unit Tests pay you back one release at a time, and over ti=
me, that's
where their value is.

-Kevin
